user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_set_initial_state_:
```c
void
MHD_connection_set_initial_state_ (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  size_t read_buf_size;

#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert ( (0 == (c->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS)) || \
               (MHD_TLS_CONN_INIT == c->tls_state) );
  mhd_assert ( (0 != (c->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS)) || \
               (MHD_TLS_CONN_NO_TLS == c->tls_state) );
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_INIT == c->state);

  c->keepalive = MHD_CONN_KEEPALIVE_UNKOWN;
  c->event_loop_info = MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_READ;

  memset (&c->rq, 0, sizeof(c->rq));
  memset (&c->rp, 0, sizeof(c->rp));

  c->write_buffer = NULL;
  c->write_buffer_size = 0;
  c->write_buffer_send_offset = 0;
  c->write_buffer_append_offset = 0;

  c->continue_message_write_offset = 0;

  c->read_buffer_offset = 0;
  read_buf_size = c->daemon->pool_size / 2;
  c->read_buffer
    = MHD_pool_allocate (c->pool,
                         read_buf_size,
                         false);
  c->read_buffer_size = read_buf_size;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the provided function MHD_connection_set_initial_state_. There are no calls to memcmp, no string comparisons, and no operations that compare or rely on null-terminated strings. The code only contains assertions, assignments, memset calls, and a pool allocation. None of these use the Standard Library function memcmp or perform string comparisons on null-terminated strings, so there are no code fragments in this function that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14. If memcmp usage exists elsewhere in the codebase or in called functions (e.g., MHD_pool_allocate), those locations would need to be reviewed separately, but they are not present in the supplied code fragment.
